awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSI: Collaborative Research: Jet Energy-Loss Tomography with a Statistically and Computationally Advanced Program Envelope (JETSCAPE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Microseconds after the Big Bang, the universe was filled with an extremely hot fluid called the Quark-Gluon Plasma. As the universe expanded, this plasma cooled and condensed into the building blocks of ordinary matter around us: protons, neutrons, and atomic nuclei. Droplets of this fluid, which exists only at temperatures above 2 trillion Kelvin, are generated and studied in the laboratory today using collisions of high-energy heavy ions at Brookhaven National Laboratory and CERN. A key method to study the Quark-Gluon Plasma is the generation of high-energy quarks and gluons in the collision, which interact with the hot plasma and emerge as "jets" of particles that are measured by experiments. These jets provide powerful tools to study the internal structure of the plasma, analogous to tomography in medical imaging. However, interpretation of jet measurements requires sophisticated numerical modeling and simulation, and comparison of theory calculations with experimental data demands advanced statistical tools. The JETSCAPE Collaboration, an interdisciplinary team of physicists, computer scientists, and statisticians, will develop a comprehensive software framework that will provide a systematic, rigorous approach to meet this challenge. Training programs, workshops, summer schools and MOOCs, will disseminate the expertise needed to modify and maintain this framework.

The JETSCAPE Collaboration will develop a scalable and portable open source software package to replace a variety of existing codes. The modular integrated software framework will consist of interacting generators to simulate (i) wave functions of the incoming nuclei, (ii) viscous fluid dynamical evolution of the hot plasma, and (iii) transport and modification of jets in the plasma. Integrated advanced statistical analysis tools will provide non-expert users with quantitative methods to validate novel theoretical descriptions of jet modification, by comparison with the complete set of current experimental data. To improve the efficiency of this computationally intensive task, the collaboration will develop trainable emulators that can accurately predict experimental observables by interpolation between full model runs, and employ accelerators such as Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) for both the fluid dynamical simulations and the modification of jets. The collaboration will create this framework with a user-friendly envelope that allows for continuous modifications, updates and improvements of each of its components. The effort will serve as a template for other fields that involve complex dynamical modeling and comparison with large data sets. It will open a new era for high-precision extraction of the internal structure of the Quark-Gluon Plasma with quantifiable uncertainties. 

This project advances the objectives of the National Strategic Computing Initiative (NSCI), an effort aimed at sustaining and enhancing the U.S. scientific, technological, and economic leadership position in High-Performance Computing (HPC) research, development, and deployment. 

This project is supported by the Division of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering and the Physics Division and the Division of Mathematical Sciences in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
About a microsecond after the Big Bang, the Universe was in a state called the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP), in which quarks and gluons, the basic constituents of the strong nuclear force, roamed freely. Due to the rapid expansion of the Universe, this plasma went through a phase transition to form bound states which interact via a much weaker version of the strong force. These bound states are called hadrons - most importantly nucleons - and constitute the building blocks of matter as we know it today. It has been only in the last two decades that accelerators have been in operation that give us the capabilities to create the conditions of temperature and density in the laboratory that are favorable for the QGP to exist. The Relativistic Heavy-Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory and the accompaniment of detector systems were built specifically to observe and study this phase of matter. Similar studies are now being undertaken at the CERN Large Hadron Collider where large nuclei are collided at high energies to recreate the conditions of the Big Bang. The experiments at RHIC have discovered a new form of ultra-dense matter with unprecedented properties, a plasma composed of unbound quarks and gluons, that appears to behave as a nearly perfect liquid. Quarks and gluons that are produced early-on in the collision at large momenta lose copious amounts of their energy and momentum while traversing the QGP - this phenomenon is called jet-energy loss. It acts as a key probe for studying the properties of the QGP.

The central problem in the study of the QGP is that its lifetime is so short and the produced quarks and gluons are not directly observable due to being confined within bound states as the plasma cools and expands. One of the main tasks in relativistic heavy-ion research is to find clear and unambiguous connections between the transient (quark-gluon) plasma state and the experimentally observable hadronic final state. The JETSCAPE project represents a collaboration between theoretical and experimental heavy-ion physicists, computer scientists, and statisticians to construct a software framework within which elaborate modular simulations of nuclear collisions can be constructed and statistically evaluated using Bayesian methods. This framework is made available to the entire community of heavy-ion physicists via regular releases, accompanied with online and in-person training schools and workshops.

As part of the JETSCAPE project, the group at Texas A&M University has developed a hadronization model, Hybrid Hadronization, which simulates the crucial step of quarks and gluons turning into hadrons. The importance of this process in the framework comes from the fact that most interesting physics questions to be addressed happen in the plasma of quarks and gluons, while the particles which are observed in detectors are hadrons.

Hybrid Hadronization is a novel concept as it combines two very different approaches to hadronization into one general framework. Individually, these two approaches, quark recombination and string fragmentation, are appropriate for either nucleus-nucleus collisions with many particles, or electron-positron and proton-proton collisions with very few particles. Hybrid Hadronization has the potential to be universally applicable to all collision systems. The group at Texas A&M has developed the Hybrid Hadronization code, implemented it into the JETSCAPE framework, tested and tuned it using electron-positron and proton-proton data together with Bayesian analysis techniques, and has studied its properties in dense systems resembling nucleus-nucleus collisions.

The group at Texas A&M has also played an important role in the first published paper with results from the completed JETSCAPE 1.0 framework, "JETSCAPE framework: p+p results".
